items.title: Make tox fail on unspecified pyXX environments
items.body:
When submitting a bug make sure you can reproduce it via ``tox -rvv`` and attach the output of that to the bug. Ideally, you should also submit a project that allows easily reproducing the bug. Thanks!

tox will fail on a "completely" unknown environment (as fixed in #1160).
However, if I have an environment list like:

```
$ tox -a
py36-sphinx2
py36-sphinx3
```

running `tox -e py36` will still run and create an environment.

Is there a way to stop this?

items.title: PEP517 in-tree build backend-path support in get-build-requires

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
Using tox 3.19, in-tree build with `backend-path` fails with:
```
.package start: get-build-requires /Users/nicolas/Workspaces/proj/.tox/.package
setting PATH=/Users/nicolas/Workspaces/proj/.tox/.package/bin:/Users/nicolas/.virtualenvs/proj-python3.8/bin:/opt/local/bin:/opt/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin
[15159] /Users/nicolas/Workspaces/proj$ /Users/nicolas/Workspaces/proj/.tox/.package/bin/python /Users/nicolas/.virtualenvs/proj-python3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/tox/helper/build_requires.py build_package '' >.tox/.package/log/.package-0.log
ERROR: invocation failed (exit code 1), logfile: /Users/nicolas/Workspaces/proj/.tox/.package/log/.package-0.log
=================================================================================== log start ====================================================================================
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/nicolas/.virtualenvs/proj-python3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/tox/helper/build_requires.py", line 7, in <module>
    backend = __import__(backend_spec, fromlist=["_trash"])
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'build_package'
```

`pyproject.toml` content is:
```
[build-system]
requires = [
  "setuptools >= 40.9.0",
  "wheel",
]
build-backend = "build_package"
backend-path = ["scripts"]
```

A quick patch of `tox/helper/build_requires.py` to use the backend paths similarly to `tox/helper/build_isolated.py` fixes the issue. I can do a PR but the patch duplicates the `_ensure_module_in_paths` function.

items.title: ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'virtualenv.seed.via_app_data'

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
Apparently tox execution can trigger an error which is specific to virtualenv, even if python reports virtualenv as installed.
```
▶ tox --version
3.19.0 imported from /home/ssbarnea/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tox/__init__.py
registered plugins:

▶ pip freeze|grep virt
virtualenv==20.0.30

▶ tox -e py36-ansible28
.package create: /home/ssbarnea/rmux/ansible-lint/.tox/.package
ERROR: invocation failed (exit code 1), logfile: /home/ssbarnea/rmux/ansible-lint/.tox/.package/log/.package-0.log
=============================================================== log start ================================================================
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'virtualenv.seed.via_app_data'

================================================================ log end =================================================================
ERROR: InvocationError for command /usr/bin/python3 -m virtualenv --no-download --python /usr/bin/python3 .package (exited with code 1)
ERROR: FAIL could not package project - v = InvocationError('/usr/bin/python3 -m virtualenv --no-download --python /usr/bin/python3 .package', 1)
```

Changing [requires](https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-requires) option does not help at all.

I also removed virtualenv completely from the machine and in this case tox failed with error bellow:
```
.tox recreate: /home/ssbarnea/rmux/ansible-lint/.tox/.tox
ERROR: invocation failed (exit code 1), logfile: /home/ssbarnea/rmux/ansible-lint/.tox/.tox/log/.tox-0.log
=============================================================== log start ================================================================
/usr/bin/python3: No module named virtualenv

================================================================ log end =================================================================
ERROR: InvocationError for command /usr/bin/python3 -m virtualenv --no-download --python /usr/bin/python3 .tox (exited with code 1)
```

Please note that this should have not happen because python3 comes with venv, and this was expected to be used instead, especially because various versions of virtualenv may be buggy/outdated.

items.title: Migration from sdist to setuptools and isolated_build

labels.name: type:question :grey_question:
labels.description: a question about how things work or if something is a bug or a feature

items.body: Coming from https://github.com/actions/virtual-environments/issues/1381#issuecomment-671360917, I tried adding a `pyproject.toml` file (as explained in https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/example/package.html): https://github.com/eine/vunit/commit/9ec4f36a7fcfa6589d64bdad1ce132cd39eb4821. However, the `setup.py` in VUnit/vunit imports some internal functions (https://github.com/VUnit/vunit/blob/master/setup.py#L14-L15). As a result, tox fails to install the package: https://github.com/eine/vunit/runs/967368728?check_suite_focus=true#step:5:23. What is the recommended approach in this case?

items.title: --sitepackages is ignored

labels.name: type:question :grey_question:
labels.description: a question about how things work or if something is a bug or a feature

items.body:
tox is ignoring the `--sitepackages` flag. This can be observed, for example, by using a dependency that requires special handling to install (and therefore must be inherited using `--sitepackages`), such as detectron2. (Of course this can also be observed by manually installing any non-default version of any package, such as from a branch or a local version installed with `pip install --editable`; tox will ignore `--sitepackages` and install the default version.)

A full example can be found at https://github.com/dHannasch/tox-sitepackages-example. I'm not sure how best to show this behavior, since a package needs to be installed outside of tox to see that `--sitepackages` does not work; this repo manually installs detectron2 on Travis, and then runs `tox --sitepackages`.

```
install:
  - python -m pip install detectron2 -f https://dl.fbaipublicfiles.com/detectron2/wheels/cu101/torch1.5/index.html
script:
  - tox --recreate -vv --sitepackages
```

The peculiar thing is that everything worked perfectly as of July30 2:18pm; that is, `--sitepackages` properly inherited the installed detectron2 from the environment.
And yet, reverting to earlier versions of tox (and even pip, since I noticed there was a new version of pip August 4) does not seem to help.
(This is difficult to show, since that repo is complicated with a lot of other things going on, but it's striking that re-running the exact same CI job on the exact same git commit fails where it passed before. I presume the difference is some non-version-pinned library I haven't thought of, but it's apparently not tox itself; some change in another library has broken `tox --sitepackages`.)

Full output is available on Travis.
```
$ python -m pip install detectron2 -f https://dl.fbaipublicfiles.com/detectron2/wheels/cu101/torch1.5/index.html
```

items.title: docs refactoring: towncrier draft + sphinx as an ext

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body:
So I happened to borrow the idea of embedding the draft Towncrier output into Sphinx docs and turned it into a native Sphinx extension: [ansible/pylibssh@f5f9ef1](https://github.com/ansible/pylibssh/pull/118/commits/f5f9ef17e51b0c80db6e48388ebb4d48ee021e91).

The basic use is:
```rst
.. towncrier-draft-entries:: |release| [UNRELEASED DRAFT]
```
(for example, there's also configuration options and defaults)

@gaborbernat would you want it here? It basically could replace the hack this generating a gitignored file. I'm considering releasing it as a standalone dist but right now it's only available as vendored copy-paste.

items.title: Generative section names don't work with empty factor

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
If I have a `tox.ini` like this:

```ini
[tox]
skipsdist = true

[testenv:foo]
commands =
    {envpython} -c "print('Hello World')"

[testenv:foo-factor]
commands =
    {envpython} -c "print('Factor given')"
    {envpython} -c "print('Hello World')"
```

Now I'd like to simplify this to use generative section names. I'd expect to either `testenv:foo{,-factor}` or `testenv:foo-{,factor}` to work. It looks like neither does.

This:

```ini
[tox]
skipsdist = true

[testenv:foo,{-factor}]
commands =
    factor: {envpython} -c "print('Factor given')"
    {envpython} -c "print('Hello World')"
```

results in:

```
$ tox -e foo-factor
ERROR: unknown environment 'foo-factor'
```

(or an empty run without any commands if `foo-factor` is added to `envlist`), while this:

```ini
[tox]
skipsdist = true

[testenv:foo-{,factor}]
commands =
    factor: {envpython} -c "print('Factor given')"
    {envpython} -c "print('Hello World')"
```

results in:

```
$ tox -e foo       
ERROR: unknown environment 'foo'
```

(as it defines an environment called `foo-`, not `foo`).

Am I missing something, or is the currently no way to do this kind of thing?

items.title: Failure to run tox on Travis CI on Python 3.6, working elsewhere

labels.name: type:question :grey_question:
labels.description: a question about how things work or if something is a bug or a feature

items.body:
Hello,

I am working with the development of psycopg3, and I'm trying to create two distributions: "psycopg3" would be pure python, "psycopg3-c" would be an add-on to improve performance but requiring more dependencies on at install time (compiler, dev headers...). What I'm trying to do is to keep both the distributions into the same git repository. So, in the [multiple-distributions branch](https://github.com/psycopg/psycopg3/tree/multiple-distributions) I'm currently testing this layout:

```
psycopg3/
+-- tox.ini
+-- psycopg3/
|     +-- setup.py
|     +-- psycopg3/
|           +-- __init__.py
|           +-- [more python code]
+-- psycopg3_c/
      +-- setup.py
      +-- [cython, c code]
```

tox seems to work well locally: from blank you can pretty much:

- clone the repos
- create a python 3.6 virtualenv and source
- pip install tox
- run `tox` in the project directory and everything gets tested ok:

```
  py36: commands succeeded
ERROR:  py37: InterpreterNotFound: python3.7
ERROR:  py38: InterpreterNotFound: python3.8
  black: commands succeeded
  flake8: commands succeeded
  mypy: commands succeeded
```

However, testing on gitlab ci fails with a problem that seems originating from the temporary package that tox creates: see [this build failure](https://travis-ci.org/github/psycopg/psycopg3/builds/712753699). Previously all the jobs were failing, now only the ones using python 3.6 it seems. Message error is 

    FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/tmp/pip-req-build-wsekflql/setup.py'

I could "fix" py 3.7 and 3.8 by [pinning setuptools and wheel versions](https://github.com/psycopg/psycopg3/compare/c2e01db0c0cf...a5c6bc1dc1a1) but that doesn't seem to affect python 3.6 tasks.

I understand that you are not responsible of what happens on Travis CI of course: I would appreciate your insight to understand why this command might fail there. Have you got idea what else could be different? Versions are:

- python 3.6.7 on Travis, 3.6.9 locally
- pip 20.1.1
- tox 3.18.1

Thank you very much!

```
  inflating: tox/config/cli/__init__.py
  inflating: tox/config/cli/env_var.py
  inflating: tox/config/cli/for_docs.py
  inflating: tox/config/cli/ini.py
  inflating: tox/config/cli/parse.py
  inflating: tox/config/cli/parser.py
```
Where do these come from? It looks like they come from virtualenv: https://github.com/pypa/virtualenv/blob/20.0.28/src/virtualenv/config/env_var.py

There is no f-string in that module though, but there is in the tox wheel:
``` python
            value = os.environ[environ_key]
            # noinspection PyBroadException
            try:
                source = f"env var {environ_key}"
                of_type = CONVERT.to(raw=value, of_type=of_type)
                return of_type, source
            except Exception as exception:
```
That has caused some problems for us when trying to run with py27...
Can anyone shed some light on this for me?

items.title: tox should map all TOX_ prefixed variables to options

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body:
Like other command line tools, tox should generically map any `TOX_FOO=bar` to environment variable too an lowercase option like `--foo=bar`.

This approach would make it easier to control and configure on both development stations and CI pipelines.

Also, implementing this would simplify the code as we would no longer need specific code that does this type of mappings for each option.

I sure that pip and ansible do this kind of mapping, better described as **configurable defaults fallback**, and likely pytest too.

items.title: [docs][level:easy] "tty" substitution example doesn't show up as a code block

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
I noticed that the code block @ https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#interactive-shell-substitution doesn't show up as code, like other similar examples above.

The fix should be easy — `s/:$/::/` @ https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/blob/3c10fd9/docs/config.rst#L722.

I'm not sending a PR hoping that this would be a good first issue for beginners.

items.title: RFE: Use a HOSTNAME environment variable instead of socket.getfqdn() in ResultLog

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body:
Hello. When I build Fedora RPM Python packages locally, I have a setup with disabled network -- to make sure the package will build fine in the official Fedora build system, which is "offline".

My setup (common to other Fedora packagers) times out when the code within runs DNS queries. tox, even when invoked very simply (e.g. via `tox -l`), calls `socket.getfqdn()`:

https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/blob/9e61b2d5ed78385c52d584adbe67fbeb44a11f34/src/tox/logs/result.py#L24

As a result, the invocation hangs for ~1 minute, then proceeds. This is a tad inconvenient, especially since `tox` might be invoked multiple times in some of our packages.

I respect that this network setup is not the most common one. However, would you accept a pull request that prefers the value of the `HOSTNAME` environment variable if set, over a call to `socket.getfqdn()`?

items.title: tox not respecting build-requires in pyproject.toml

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
The project I'm working on uses scikit-build. scikit-build provides a wrapper around the `setup()` call in a setup.py that calls the CMake project before delegating the remainder of the install to setuptools. This means before setup.py can be run, the build requirements (which include sckit-build, cmake, and ninja) specified in pyproject.toml must be installed. When I install the package with pip, the build requirements are installed first, as expected, and the package installs successfully. However, when running tox, it doesn't install the build requirements and so it fails to import the setup.py.

I created a [minimal broken example project](https://github.com/ktbarrett/broken-tox/commit/ec9f55bb6f4a9aeb47dff7a795febf3571698407).

```
> tox -rvv
using tox.ini: /home/kaleb/dev/demo/tox.ini (pid 79373)
  removing /home/kaleb/dev/demo/.tox/log
using tox-3.16.1 from /home/kaleb/miniconda3/envs/hello2/lib/python3.8/site-packages/tox/__init__.py (pid 79373)
GLOB start: packaging 
GLOB sdist-make: /home/kaleb/dev/demo/setup.py
[79376] /home/kaleb/dev/demo$ /home/kaleb/miniconda3/envs/hello2/bin/python setup.py sdist --formats=zip --dist-dir /home/kaleb/dev/demo/.tox/dist >.tox/log/GLOB-0.log
ERROR: invocation failed (exit code 1), logfile: /home/kaleb/dev/demo/.tox/log/GLOB-0.log
========================================================================= log start ==========================================================================
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "setup.py", line 1, in <module>
    from skbuild import setup
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'skbuild'

========================================================================== log end ===========================================================================
ERROR: FAIL could not package project - v = InvocationError('/home/kaleb/miniconda3/envs/hello2/bin/python setup.py sdist --formats=zip --dist-dir /home/kaleb/dev/demo/.tox/dist', 1)
```

After looking at the [legacy package build code](https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/blob/master/src/tox/package/builder/legacy.py), I don't see where it handles build requirements as specified in a pyproject.toml at all. I then added `isolated_build=true` to see what the behavior of the isolated package builder was and I get:

```
> tox -rvv
using tox.ini: /home/kaleb/dev/demo/tox.ini (pid 79542)
  removing /home/kaleb/dev/demo/.tox/log
using tox-3.16.1 from /home/kaleb/miniconda3/envs/hello2/lib/python3.8/site-packages/tox/__init__.py (pid 79542)
skipping sdist step
__________________________________________________________________________ summary ___________________________________________________________________________
  congratulations :)
```

So it skips sdist then does nothing...

Perhaps I'm missing something?

items.title: Option to bypass package installation on demand

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body:
Currently if you want to separate tox setup and run via:

```
tox -e py --notest
tox -e py
```

The second invocation still builds the package and installs it. I suggest adding ``--skip-package-install`` that would skip this step and go ahead straight with running the test suite? (especially useful in CIs to avoid the redundant rebuild and install) @asottile what you think?

items.title: Data Files missing in package installation by tox
items.body:
Hello!

I have a data directory within my package that contains data subdirectories. Maintaining these subdirectories is paramount to my unit tests since it mimics the architecture that my package has ti deal with. 

The problem is that, although the files in the data folder get installed properly in all the environments I've set up in tox, the subfolders are not there. This means that tests that should work fine end up failing. 

Is there a reason why I have missing directories?
My tox file looks like this: 
```
[tox]
envlist =
```

This happens with all projects... so there is something fundamentally broken (on my machine).

I tracked the problem down to cpython deprecating HTMLParser unescape

setuptools was using this, but did some changes in 41.1.0

items.title: On py38 envs, need: setenv = PYTHONPATH={envdir}/lib/python3.8

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
I use an environment called "unit" to run unit tests (`tox -e unit`). The environment needs a python module on `.tox/unit/lib/<pythonversion>` to make the unit tests work (FYI, that module is deployed by a different component, but it is a dependency for one of the programs tested here).

In previous Ubuntu distros, where py35 and py36 are the default interpreters, `sys.path` already included said folder (ie. `.tox/unit/lib/python3.5/module.py` or `.tox/unit/lib/python3.6/module.py`).

However, in py38, the default `sys.path` includes `.tox/unit/lib/python3.8/site-packages` but not the previous folder. Hence, the extra `PYTHONPATH` config mentioned in the subject.

I'm not sure if this is a bug or something expected. I tried with tox `3.13.2` and the current latest version (`3.14.6`) with same results.

FWIW, the mentioned workaround works even when the interpreter changes to the previous versions (so, backward compatible).

Thank you,
-Alvaro.

items.title: tox need an option to override basepython for specific environment

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body:
I do have a valid use-case where I want the CI/CD system to assure that when `tox -e devel` runs, it will use a specific python version.

For practical reasons the `devel` environment does not mention any specific python, as the code is supposed to run well with any python. Still, when doing CI/CD testing. we want to be sure that we test with specific versions.

At this moment the only tuning option is `--discover` but that one is only overriding the lookup directories for finding python executables. If this specific python interpreter is located in the same folder as the other ones, you would be able to use this option to enforce use of a specific one.

The reality is the on most Linux distributions all python executables will be installed in the same folder.

There are two workarounds that I theoretically possible but both of them look over-complicated:
* create a virtualenv using `--python python3.8` and give that virtualenv bin directory to tox 
discovery.
* create a new folder and create a symlink for the interpreter, give this folder to `tox --discovery`.
* create an additional `py38-devel` environment, which uses `basepython`, and inherits all the other options from the `devel` one.

If possible, I would prefer a ``--python`` option added to tox which is behaving similar to the one in virtualenv.

items.title: tox ignores directories without an `__init__.py` in python 3

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body:
Apologies if I am missing something here, but this issue seems worth flagging, as the use case is quite banal. Python 3.3 introduced [Implicit Namespace Packages](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0420/) :

> Allowing implicit namespace packages means that the requirement to provide an __init__.py file can be dropped completely

However, tox 3.14 will _ignore_ any directories which don't contain a `__init__.py` when it builds and installs a version of the package from source into `.tox/{py3env}/lib`.

This leads to a situation where expected directories are not installed, and tests fail due to broken import paths, because an `__init__.py` was missing which Python 3.3+ doesn't actually require.

Given that Python 3 is the standard these days, it seems that tox should either know to disregard missing `__init__.py` files for Python 3.3+ or at least warn the user that directories have been ignored for that reason.

Environment

- tox 3.14.6
- python 3.7.6
- pip 20.0.2

`tox.ini`:

```
[tox]
envlist =
    # Commands to run against multiple Python versions
    {py37}-test

[testenv]
basepython = python3.7
setenv =
    PYTHONPATH={toxinidir}/tests
    PYTHONUNBUFFERED=yes
usedevelop = false
deps =
    pytest
    pytest-cov
    .[test]
install_command = pip install {opts} {packages} .[test]
commands =
    {posargs:py.test}

[testenv:py37-test]
passenv =
    TEST_*
```

items.title: Pass PIP_EXTRA_INDEX_URL by default

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body:
tox currently passes `PIP_INDEX_URL` as a default environment config. This parameter allows the user to specify a package index.

pip supports another configuration parameter for additional indexes; `PIP_EXTRA_INDEX_URL`.

I think it would be beneficial to pass `PIP_EXTRA_INDEX_URL` by default in addition to `PIP_INDEX_URL` to support index configuration parameters transparently

items.title: Irrelevant Error message for invalid argument when running outside a directory with tox support files

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
When running outside a directory with tox support files. For invalid aruguments,  
without showing Unrecognized Arguments Error, it shows an error on missing tox supported files.
```
nkpro@SR:~/notoxini$ tox --invalid
ERROR: tox config file (either pyproject.toml, tox.ini, setup.cfg) not found
nkpro@SR:~/withtoxini$ tox --invalid
usage: tox [--version] [-h] [--help-ini] [-v] [-q] [--showconfig] [-l] [-a] [-c CONFIGFILE] [-e envlist] [--devenv ENVDIR] [--notest] [--sdistonly] [-p VAL] [-o] [--parallel--safe-build]
           [--installpkg PATH] [--develop] [-i URL] [--pre] [-r] [--result-json PATH] [--discover PATH [PATH ...]] [--hashseed SEED] [--force-dep REQ] [--sitepackages] [--alwayscopy]
           [-s [val]] [--workdir PATH]
           [args [args ...]]
tox: error: unrecognized arguments: --invalid
```

items.title: tox --help-ini shows an error when run outside a directory with tox support files

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
similar to issue #1509  
Running tox --help-ini from no directory in particular (one that doesn't have a tox.ini etc.) shows an error:  
```
⊙  tox --help                                                                                                                                                                                     nkpro@Prime
ERROR: tox config file (either pyproject.toml, tox.ini, setup.cfg) not found
envdir          <path>   default: {toxworkdir}/{envname}
set venv directory -- be very careful when changing this as tox will remove this directory when recreating an environment
...
```

items.title: tox  3.14.5 incompatible with virtualenv 20

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
I am running into issues when using the very latest versions of tox and virtualenv. I am running things in a clean environment:


If I create a simple ``tox.ini`` file that specifies a requirement that is not in the current environment:

```
[tox]
envlist = test
requires =
```

If I add:

```
    virtualenv < 20
```

to the ``requires`` section, everything works fine.

items.title: tox -p auto ignores usedevelop = true when some environments need it

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
Steps to reproduce:

- git clone https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.file
- cd zope.file
- git checkout 1e88bb9e89401c1e615c54cf2885f75492a95251  # in case I push a workaround for this bug
- tox -e coverage # works fine!
- tox -p auto -e coverage # works fine!
- tox -p auto -e py38,coverage # coverage is shown as 0%

The reason coverage is computed as 0% in the last step is that tox ignores `[testenv:coverage] usedevelop = true` and recreates the '.tox/coverage' virtualenv using a pip install without --editable.

Here's the output of `tox -rvv`:

items.title: exited with code -11 (SIGSEGV)

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
When running tox locally, I run into this, however, I can not reproduce it in my other local projects or on Travis CI (the tests just passed normally). I have checked that the tests themselves are not failing through my terminal and Travis CI.

Here's my tox.ini file, only the '**behave**' testenv passed normally.

```ini
[tox]
skipsdist=True

[testenv:migrate]
deps =
    -rrequirements.txt
commands =
    python manage.py makemigrations --check

[testenv:flake8]
deps =
    flake8
commands =
	flake8 --exclude=migrations,venv,.tox --count --show-source --ignore E501
	
[testenv:behave]
deps =
    -rrequirements.txt
commands =
	python manage.py behave


[testenv:test]
deps =
    -rrequirements.txt
commands =
	python manage.py test
```

The log is as follows (I choose a rather simply executed testenv as all 3 failing ones have same results):

items.title: When generating sdist, tox ignores environment python, which leads to import errors

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
### Summary
tox ignores the python executable in PATH when creating the sdist. In cases where setup.py contains import requirements that are not available in the system Python, imports and the sdist packaging fails.

### Example
From https://github.com/biocommons/uta-align (specifically 731de09):

```
snafu$ tox -rvv
using tox.ini: /home/reece/projects/biocommons/uta-align/tox.ini (pid 25874)
  removing /home/reece/projects/biocommons/uta-align/.tox/log
using tox-3.14.1 from /home/reece/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/tox/__init__.py (pid 25874)
GLOB start: packaging 
GLOB sdist-make: /home/reece/projects/biocommons/uta-align/setup.py
  removing /home/reece/projects/biocommons/uta-align/.tox/dist
[25877] /home/reece/projects/biocommons/uta-align$ /usr/bin/python3 setup.py sdist --formats=zip --dist-dir .tox/dist >.tox/log/GLOB-0.log
ERROR: invocation failed (exit code 1), logfile: /home/reece/projects/biocommons/uta-align/.tox/log/GLOB-0.log
================================================================================= log start ==================================================================================
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "setup.py", line 5, in <module>
    from Cython.Build import cythonize, build_ext
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'Cython'

================================================================================== log end ===================================================================================
```

Note that sdist is invoked with `/usr/bin/python3`, even though:
```
snafu$ which python3.7
/home/reece/projects/biocommons/uta-align/venv/3.7/bin/python3.7
snafu$ which python3
/home/reece/projects/biocommons/uta-align/venv/3.7/bin/python3

```

Furtheremore, when I invoke sdist with the environment python, it works fine:

```
snafu$ python3 setup.py sdist --formats=zip --dist-dir /home/reece/projects/biocommons/uta-align/.tox/dist
WARNING: The wheel package is not available.
WARNING: The wheel package is not available.
/usr/lib/python3.7/distutils/dist.py:274: UserWarning: Unknown distribution option: 'use_scm_version'
  warnings.warn(msg)
running sdist
running egg_info
writing uta_align.egg-info/PKG-INFO
writing dependency_links to uta_align.egg-info/dependency_links.txt
writing requirements to uta_align.egg-info/requires.txt

```

### Additional information
The documentation for `basepython` says: "For any pyXY test environment name the underlying pythonX.Y executable will be searched in your system PATH." Setting `basepython` does not affect the sdist packaging phase.

items.title: (PyPy3, Windows) no `python` in tox.ini but: WARNING: test command found but not installed in testenv

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
```
WARNING: test command found but not installed in testenv
  cmd: C:\Program Files (x86)\Python36-32\python.EXE
  env: C:\epc\pytest-twisted\.tox\pypy3-defaultreactor
Maybe you forgot to specify a dependency? See also the whitelist_externals envconfig setting.

DEPRECATION WARNING: this will be an error in tox 4 and above!
```

Note in the last log block below that `tox.ini` doesn't even call python anywhere.  The error is similar to that in #1389 which points it out as a virtualenv bug fixed over in https://github.com/pypa/virtualenv/pull/1400 but it seems that didn't make it into anything but `legacy`?  In #1389 it is pointed out that:

> The problem is that pypy.exe gets installed into "Scripts", but only "bin" added to the PATH:

I see the same below.  But, when I manually create and activate a virtualenv I see the opposite.  scripts is in the path and bin is not...  https://github.com/pypa/virtualenv/issues/1649  Anyways, I have to do some other things for the moment but hopefully can look more at this later.

Originally observed over at https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest-twisted/pull/85#issuecomment-589496574.

items.title: Nested toxworkdir as default value to environment substitution

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
Hi,

Your docs says that substitutions can be nested, but when we do something like this:
```
--junitxml {env:JUNIT_REPORT_DIR:{toxworkdir}}/junit.{envname}.xml
```
we end up with something like this for example: `--junitxml /junit.py35-ci.xml`
Like we do it here: https://github.com/snowflakedb/snowflake-connector-python/blob/97cc99a8a81fd5b78ddeeb2767795f275dd51ab0/tox.ini#L29

Is this a design decision? Can we only nest environmental substitutions into environmental substitutions?
Do you maybe know of a workaround for this issue?

items.title: Allow environment creation but don't run the tox.ini commands on it

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body:
Hi, I think a really cool feature about tox would be to be able to create virtualenvs with the requirements/local packages of a environment located in tox.ini. This would allow to use this virtualenv later on to run custom commands or using tox.ini commands. 

The use case is: I need to create a virtualenv and then some time later run some pytest tests on it. The only alternative I currently have is to create the virtualenv and pass a name of a test that does not exists(telling pytest to ignore errors) so the virtualenv gets created and later on pass the true test names.

items.title: conditional configuration depending on if environment variable is set

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body:
## Goal

- If `SPHINX_VERSION` environment variable set, install dep `sphinx=={env:SPHINX_VERSION}`
- Otherwise, install dep `sphinx` (without the `==`).

The motivation is to test against latest `sphinx` when running `tox`, but on CI we would like to test against a matrix as well as locally be able to `SPHINX_VERSION=1.8.5 tox` for example.

## Goofy Workaround

```ini
[tox]
envlist = py

[testenv]
deps =
    sphinx{env:SPHINX_VERSION:}
```

and require that people include the `==` in the environment variable, e.g., `SPHINX_VERSION===1.8.5 tox`.  It works, but it just feels so wrong.

## Ugly hack on tox

Working within the current replacement "language"

https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/blob/b7a1559bd8c61917eec1c590ead9b8fbbe19d444/src/tox/config/__init__.py#L1583-L1593

I came up with a not so intuitive "`env_set`" substitution pattern: `{env_set:KEY:value}` will expand to `value` if and only if `KEY` is set in the environment.  If `KEY` is not set, then it expands to the empty string.  This lets me do this:

```ini
deps =
    sphinx{env_set:SPHINX_VERSION:==}{env:SPHINX_VERSION:}
```

Which I totally concede is rather obtuse.  Like yeah...it technically works, but honestly how useful is it outside of my specific case?  (Patch omitted, it's nearly the same as `def _replace_env` in that file).

--------------------

Is there a better way to approach this?  I tried to find a way to define the [`extra` env marker](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0508/#id24) but I don't think I can or even should.  I can also define a `[sphinx]` section and set a `version` field and do `sphinx=={env:SPHINX_VERSION:{[sphinx]version}}`, but then I have to remember to update `[sphinx]version` when new releases roll out.

I'd be interested in implementing any version of a feature that lets me do this.  For example, what if we added support for like `{if:<condition>:<value>}`?  Trying to propose ideas that don't change the formatting of the regex, but what about something like allowing us to run raw python code?  `python -c 'import os; v = os.getenv("SPHINX_VERSION", None); d = "sphinx==" + v if v else "sphinx"; print(d)'`

I feel like raw python code might be nice to have, but it also feels like a security problem.

I understand if this is closed as #wontfix since I can just put the `==` in my env vars.  But I'd love to be able to solve this in a more intuitive way.  Thank you for any input / suggestions / tips! :slightly_smiling_face:

items.title: The job exceeded the maximum log length, and has been terminated.

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
My package depends on nightly releases of both tensorflow and tensorflow-probability. Tests were [successful](https://travis-ci.org/adamhaber/stan2tfp/builds/634428345) last time I updated the package; then, probably due to a dependency change in tf-nightly or tfp-nightly, the build fails. I've tried to update the dependencies in setup.py to `tf-nightly` but for some reason this installs tf 1.15 instead of tf 2.1, on which tfp-nightly depends. I _think_ I was able to fix this by updating pip itself:
```
commands = 
    python -m pip install --upgrade pip
    pip install tf-nightly --upgrade
    python setup.py test
```
But now I get the error message mentioned above, and I'm not sure how to debug this since I can't see where the build actually fails.

[This](https://travis-ci.org/adamhaber/stan2tfp/builds/639097312) is the latest build attempt, and [this](https://github.com/adamhaber/stan2tfp) is the actual repo with tox.ini and setup.py. Thanks in advance!

items.title: Can't run different commands per platform

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
I want to run a different command depending on the platform (e.g. windows, linux, macos).
In the I saw the deps section being specified for different envs ([conditional settings](https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#factors)).

However, conditional commands aren't running for me. I have

```
[testenv:sanity]
whitelist_externals =
    touch
commands =
    touch /tmp/works-generic
    linux: touch /tmp/works-linux
    darwin: touch /tmp/works-macos
```

Only the first command runs.

I've tried tox 3.0.0 and tox 3.14.3 with no difference

items.title: include the HTTP proxy environment variables in PASSENV by default

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body:
Tox doesn't include HTTP proxy variables (`HTTP_PROXY`, `HTTPS_PROXY` and `NO_PROXY`) in `PASSENV` by default. As those variables basically say "you need to use this proxy or network access won't work" they seem like something that would be required for any network-related test.

I suggest that the variables are added to the list of ones included in `PASSENV` by default.

#258 was raised about this issue, before `PASSENV` existed as far as I can see, and appears to have been accepted with the resolution being that tox passed all environment variables. Presumably at some point, that was restricted again and `PASSENV` introduced, but the proxy variables weren't considered at that time?

items.title: Immediately forwarding Ctrl+C to child processes considered harmful

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
I have a test runner which install unittests's [signal handlers](https://docs.python.org/3/library/unittest.html#signal-handling). When hitting Ctrl+C in tox, the test runner sometimes receives a SIGINT while in the process of shutting down. This seemed wrong, and I traced it down to tox unconditionally forwarding any received SIGINT. The situation however is that _all_ foreground processes receive the SIGINT, not just tox, and when tox forwards it the test runner receives the SIGINT twice. My solution is to make tox wait for processes to go away on their own before starting to send signals.

Anyway, here is my patch (which no longer applies after #1493, but you get the idea):

```diff
diff --git a/src/tox/action.py b/src/tox/action.py
index 10707b4..9f826a0 100644
--- a/src/tox/action.py
+++ b/src/tox/action.py
@@ -18,6 +18,7 @@ from tox.reporter import Verbosity
 from tox.util.lock import get_unique_file
 from tox.util.stdlib import is_main_thread
 
+WAIT_SUICIDE = 0.5
 WAIT_INTERRUPT = 0.3
 WAIT_TERMINATE = 0.2
 
@@ -177,7 +178,7 @@ class Action(object):
     def handle_interrupt(self, process):
         """A three level stop mechanism for children - INT -> TERM -> KILL"""
         msg = "from {} {{}} pid {}".format(os.getpid(), process.pid)
-        if process.poll() is None:
+        if self._wait(process, WAIT_SUICIDE) is None:
             self.info("KeyboardInterrupt", msg.format("SIGINT"))
             process.send_signal(signal.CTRL_C_EVENT if sys.platform == "win32" else signal.SIGINT)
             if self._wait(process, WAIT_INTERRUPT) is None:
@@ -193,7 +194,7 @@ class Action(object):
         if sys.version_info >= (3, 3):
             # python 3 has timeout feature built-in
             try:
-                process.communicate(timeout=WAIT_INTERRUPT)
+                process.communicate(timeout=timeout)
             except subprocess.TimeoutExpired:
                 pass
         else:
```

I think `pip install ".[extra]"` could be simulated?

items.title: In parallel mode, tox marks skipped interpreters as succeded.

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
Say I have no Python3.3 interpreter on my machine.
The following tox.ini:
```
[tox]
envlist = py33
skip_missing_interpreters = True
```

would of course yield: 

```
python3 -m tox
GLOB sdist-make: /xxx/yyy/setup.py
py33 recreate: /xxx/yyy/.tox/py33
SKIPPED: InterpreterNotFound: python3.3
__________________________________________________________________ summary ___________________________________________________________________
SKIPPED:  py33: InterpreterNotFound: python3.3
```
but when run in parallel, we get:
```
python3 -m tox -p auto
GLOB sdist-make: /xxx/yyy/setup.py
✔ OK py33 in 0.22 seconds
__________________________________________________________________ summary ___________________________________________________________________
  py33: commands succeeded
  congratulations :)
```

That could make a user to think that his tests are green while they simply … did not run.
Tested with tox 3.14.3.

items.title: Editorial: consider offering alternative to whitelist_externals

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
Using whitelist (and its counterpart) isn't exactly welcoming. While migrating away from it entirely might be hard due to compatibility considerations, it'd be nice if configuration files from projects that build on this technology could avoid it.

See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-knodel-terminology for additional context.

items.title: Weird bug when using Cython

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
I have attached the project archive for reproducibility purposes. In short, I am running on OSX with the following
```bash
~> python3 --version
Python 3.7.5
```

Once you download the project archive (`tox-report.zip`), simply run the following (outputs trimmed):
```bash
~> unzip tox-report.zip
~> cd tox-report
~/tox-report> python3 -m venv venv
~/tox-report> source venv/bin/activate
~/tox-report> pip install --upgrade cython tox
~/tox-report> python setup.py build # to generate the .c file
~/tox-report> tox
```

The command fails with
```bash
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'mylib.mydot_cy'
```

However, the first two lines of `tox` output are as follows:
```bash
.package create: /Users/eaytard/tox-report/.tox/.package
.package installdeps: setuptools>=42.0.2, wheel>=0.33.6, cython>=0.29.14
```
which indicates that `tox` successfully parses `pyproject.toml`. Moreover, when I check the environment's site packages, I see the following:
```bash
~/tox-report> ls -al .tox/py37/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mylib
total 1824
drwxr-xr-x   9 eaytard  staff     288 Dec 24 00:16 .
drwxr-xr-x  17 eaytard  staff     544 Dec 24 00:16 ..
-rw-r--r--   1 eaytard  staff       0 Dec 24 00:16 __init__.py
drwxr-xr-x   5 eaytard  staff     160 Dec 24 00:16 __pycache__
-rw-r--r--   1 eaytard  staff      99 Dec 24 00:16 mydot.py
-rw-r--r--   1 eaytard  staff  750544 Dec 24 00:16 mydot_cy.c
-rwxr-xr-x   1 eaytard  staff  166780 Dec 24 00:16 mydot_cy.cpython-37m-darwin.so
-rw-r--r--   1 eaytard  staff      88 Dec 24 00:16 mydot_cy.pxd
-rw-r--r--   1 eaytard  staff     146 Dec 24 00:16 mydot_py.py
```

Clearly, `python setup.py sdist` packages the library properly with the built C-files from `python setup.py build`. I can also see the shared object in place.

I simply do not understand why my tests fail with the `ModuleNotFoundError` exception. Am I missing something very trivial, or do you think this might be a bug?

**NOTE.** If I instead run
```bash
~> unzip tox-report.zip
~> cd tox-report
~/tox-report> python3 -m venv venv
~/tox-report> source venv/bin/activate
~/tox-report> pip install --upgrade tox
~/tox-report> pip install -e .
~/tox-report> tox
```
the tests pass. I believe that this has something to do with proper merging of different environments.

[tox-report.zip](https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/files/3996546/tox-report.zip)

items.title: Environment without envdir

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body:
Is there any way to define a tox environment that does not create an `envdir`, but *only* runs an external command (in `whitelist_externals`)?

One example that I have in mind is a `clean` environment so that `tox -e clean` would clean all built/testing artifacts, including the `.tox` directory itself. At least on Windows, deleting `.tox` while there are still open files inside of it is not possible.

I did come across https://github.com/obestwalter/tox-direct that looks like it's going in the right direction. Is there any other (cleaner/built-in) way to have `tox` "just run a command" without creating an `envdir` in `.tox` (or even touching the `.tox` directory at all)?

Are there any good alternatives to cleaning? I do like to include a `Makefile` that has `make clean`, but that's rather unix-specific, and I was hoping to have `tox` by itself as a platform-independent solution for *all* dev-related tasks.

items.title: tox fails to recognize my own package as first party
items.body:
I have a project which uses `tox`. And I run `flake8` in it. Until now everything worked fine, until I decided to run flake8 on tests also. 

When I call `flake8 ./tests` I get some output. Then I can fix it. Now I have no warnings whatsoever in the tests folder. But something strange happens when I run it in tox (I am 100% sure, that the packages like WPS or isort have the same versions as the ones I use locally). Basically I get `isort` warnings. The problem looks like this:

```python3
from freezegun import freeze_time

from foo.bar import baz
```

So I have a 3rd party lib import above the import from my lib. And everything is fine here, `vscode` with flake8 installed or running flake8 in terminal both don't give any warnings here. The problem is, I think, that somehow `foo` gets treated like a 3rd party lib here, so e.g. in this case, flake wants me to delete the newline between those two.

I basically tried everything (e.g. `pytest-flake8`, but it's not good, since it also runs tests, which I have in the other tox job). Is there any way to solve this, cuz my pipelines keep falling due to this.

P.S `noqa`ing IXXX warnings is not the solution here, since I want them, but not in a wrong way, which I presented above.

P.S 2 I have `known_first_party=foo` in the `[isort]` section in my `setup.cfg`

```
python (/project/bin/python) is {u'executable': u'/project/bin/python', u'name': u'python', u'version_info': [2, 7, 12, u'final', 0], u'sysplatform': u'linux2', u'version': u'2.7.12 (default, Oct  8 2019, 14:14:10) \n[GCC 5.4.0 20160609]', u'is_64': True}
py36-django111 uses None
ERROR: InterpreterNotFound: python3.6
py36-django111 finish: getenv /project/.tox/py36-django111 after 0.02 seconds
```
#### Notes
- It works fine when I run `tox -e py27-django111` and `tox -e py35-django111`
- I am running it inside a docker container

items.title: new importlib-metadata release causes tox to break pip on Python<3.8

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
This line:
https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/blob/master/setup.cfg#L41

Causes pip to end up installing invalid dependencies and then barfing about them at runtime:
```
AssertionError: Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "setup.py", line 10, in <module>
    author_email='test@example.com',
  File "/data/jenkins/shiningpanda/jobs/7ec1442c/virtualenvs/d41d8cd9/lib/python3.6/site-packages/setuptools/__init__.py", line 145, in setup
    return distutils.core.setup(**attrs)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.6/distutils/core.py", line 134, in setup
    ok = dist.parse_command_line()
  File "/data/jenkins/shiningpanda/jobs/7ec1442c/virtualenvs/d41d8cd9/lib/python3.6/site-packages/setuptools/dist.py", line 707, in parse_command_line
    result = _Distribution.parse_command_line(self)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.6/distutils/dist.py", line 472, in parse_command_line
    args = self._parse_command_opts(parser, args)
  File "/data/jenkins/shiningpanda/jobs/7ec1442c/virtualenvs/d41d8cd9/lib/python3.6/site-packages/setuptools/dist.py", line 1014, in _parse_command_opts
    nargs = _Distribution._parse_command_opts(self, parser, args)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.6/distutils/dist.py", line 528, in _parse_command_opts
    cmd_class = self.get_command_class(command)
  File "/data/jenkins/shiningpanda/jobs/7ec1442c/virtualenvs/d41d8cd9/lib/python3.6/site-packages/setuptools/dist.py", line 833, in get_command_class
    ep.require(installer=self.fetch_build_egg)
  File "/data/jenkins/shiningpanda/jobs/7ec1442c/virtualenvs/d41d8cd9/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2465, in require
    items = working_set.resolve(reqs, env, installer, extras=self.extras)
  File "/data/jenkins/shiningpanda/jobs/7ec1442c/virtualenvs/d41d8cd9/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 791, in resolve
    raise VersionConflict(dist, req).with_context(dependent_req)
pkg_resources.ContextualVersionConflict: (importlib-metadata 1.1.0 (/data/jenkins/shiningpanda/jobs/7ec1442c/virtualenvs/d41d8cd9/lib/python3.6/site-packages), Requirement.parse('importlib-metadata<1,>=0.12; python_version < "3.8"'), {'tox'})
```

Honestly, this is arguably a pip bug, since 1.0.0 still meets the requirements, but it's likely more pragmatic to just change the requirement in your `setup.cfg` to be `<2.0`.

items.title: tox with shared workdir across multiple platforms and repositories

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body:
There is one use-case where tox does not work well, or at least not without extensive changes made in tox.ini which make its its maintenance hard to understand and use. I will try to describe the use case hoping that we endup with a good solution, one that we also document and one that can easily be adopted.  Ideally we should aim to find a solution that could address this topic even without having to alter most tox.ini find in the wild.

# Multi-platform use case and shared filesystem
I am developer which works on a python project using tox which has tests which  need to pass not only on various python versions, but also on multiple platforms, like linux/osx/macos for example.  As is always recommended to test changes locally before create a change-request, I do have a set of hosts where I run tox on. 

To avoid having to rsync my changes among all these machines I do keep my source code in a shared disk (NFS, SAMBA,...). 

This means that I should be able to run tox from each of these machines and get the results. Well, not really because the `.tox` environments are not isolated between machines, and they are clearly not portable.

In the past, on few personal projects I used a trick to add the platform in environment name and use a launcher (makefile) that passed correct name to tox. Not only ugly, inconvenient but also a deal breaker due to the modification of default env names for all the other developers which may don't care about other-platforms. I kinda see their point: why to worsen the UX for most people just to cover for such an advanced use-case.

# Idea 1

I observed that one tool is not affected at all about this issue: pre-commit. This is because pre-commit creates its temporary environments in a location that is outside the repository. This means that this is unlikely to clash among platforms. In fact even if the entire user home directory would be network based the tool could easily include the platform name as part of the hashing when creating its environments. In fact the use of official caching folder has other advantages as this could easily be wiped, or stored on faster filesystems than the code itself. 

One fun aspect of this approach is that we could experimental add a TOX_SHARED_WORKDIR variable that would optionally enable the new location of the work directory. Just putting a custom directory for tox work dir would not work because the tool itself needs to be aware that multiple code repositories are using the same caching folder, only a name or hash based solution could avoid clashing inside the "centralized workdir" (likely centralized not between machines but between repositories).

# other ideas?

items.title: Tox does not work with Windows x86 embeddable zip file

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
> Important: This may be an upstream bug in `virtualenv`, but I don't know enough about its usage and how it's being invoked by tox to determine this.

In Windows, tox does not work with windows x86 embeddable zip file. See [Python Releases for Windows](https://www.python.org/downloads/windows/). For both examples, I will use [Python 3.7.5 - Oct. 15, 2019](https://www.python.org/downloads/release/python-375/) to demonstrate - but it is worth noting I have tried with versions 3.5, 3.6, 3.7, and 3.8.

# Example of expected/working output
Download [Windows x86-64 executable installer](https://www.python.org/ftp/python/3.7.5/python-3.7.5-amd64.exe) and install to `C:\Python\`

> NOTE: `basepython` does not need to be explicitly stated here, but I have done that to demonstrate that it works as intended with this specified in this way

## Configuration
```tox.ini
[tox]
envlist = py37

[testenv]
basepython =
    py37: C:\Python\python.exe
setenv =
    PYTHONPATH = {toxinidir}
deps =
    -r{toxinidir}/requirements_dev.txt
commands =
    pip install -U pip
    pytest
```

# Reproduce

Download [Windows x86-64 embeddable zip file](https://www.python.org/ftp/python/3.7.5/python-3.7.5-embed-amd64.zip) & extract the zip file to `C:\python3.7`. Delete .tox folder for clean working environment.

## Configuration
```tox.ini
[tox]
envlist = py37

[testenv]
basepython =
    py37: C:\python3.7\python.exe
setenv =
    PYTHONPATH = {toxinidir}
deps =
    -r{toxinidir}/requirements_dev.txt
commands =
    pip install -U pip
    pytest
```

## Further validation
Open `C:\python3.7\python.exe` in the file and import `site` to validate the embeddable zip is working as expected

```ipython
Python 3.7.5 (tags/v3.7.5:5c02a39a0b, Oct 15 2019, 00:11:34) [MSC v.1916 64 bit (AMD64)] on win32
>>> import site
>>> site
<module 'site' from 'C:\\python3.7\\python37.zip\\site.pyc'>
>>>
```

# Final Thoughts

Forgive my ignorance here, I feel like I may be missing something obvious... Installing multiple versions of python doesn't seem to be very straight forward to me... if this isn't the intended way to install/test using multiple versions of Python in windows then what is? I've looked over the [docs](https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/examples.html) but I don't see anything in there addressing this seemingly obvious concern (this applies irrespective of OS).

If I'm going to have my developers begin using tox before every PR, I'd like them test on all versions that the CICD pipeline is going to test so that they don't submit a PR that works on their machine but fails the quality gate

items.title: tox breaks `getpass.getuser` on Windows

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
The function `getpass.getuser` should be an platform agnostic way of getting the current user. This works fine on Windows as long as the `USERNAME` environment variable is set. However, as tox doesn't pass environment variables this is broken in tox environments.

This leads to really confusing bugs, for example https://github.com/gitpython-developers/GitPython/issues/356 where the root cause was even not detected.

I suggest you pass `USERNAME` per default to tox environments.

items.title: tox throwing an error whenever it does not find a version of Python installed on system.

labels.name: needs:reproducer
labels.description: ideally a failing test marked as xfail. If that is not possible exact instructions to reproduce

items.body:
`tox` has been throwing the following error message whenever it encounters a version of Python (mentioned in the `tox.ini` file) which isn't installed on the system.

Windows 10
python 3.7.4
tox == 3.14.0

items.title: Tox uses system python istead of virtual (WARNING: test command found but not installed in testenv)

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
I use this initial `tox.ini` file

```ini
[tox]
envlist=python37
skipsdist = True

[testenv:dev3]
commands =
    {envpython} --version
```

Which produce this warningÉ

```
dev3 finish: run-test-post  after 0.00 seconds
_________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ summary _________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
ERROR:   dev3: commands failed
```

If I understand correctly tox creates a virual environment and do all operation inside that environment. I didn't instruct tox to do commands outside of venv! Why I get these warnings?

I have found similar issues, but they are more complicated issues. This is a very clear and easy-to-reproduce issue.

I use:

 - Win10
 - Version 10.0.18362 Build 18362
 - python 3.7.5
 - tox==3.14.0
 - A brand new python only with tox. No other packages

items.title: Add --durations flag

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body:
Durations are reported with `-vv`, but it might be useful to have it just by itself via `--durations`, since `-vv` is very verbose indeed (including pip progress etc).

Related issue: https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/issues/470

items.title: [question] Any way to avoid "current" python as basepython?
items.body:
Hi,

first of all, thanks for your great work on tox :)

I have a question regarding the base Python executables used by tox to create virtualenvs.

I have a dedicated virtual environment into which tox is installed. The tox script is symlinked to `~/.local/bin` to have it in `PATH`.

I've noticed that, whenever tox needs to create a new virtualenv, if the required Python version matches the one tox is running with, the new virtualenv is created with tox's "own" Python as base Python (as opposed to looking for the executable in `PATH`).

This leads to the creation of a virtualenv using another virtualenv's Python executable as base Python, which I'd like to avoid - instead, I'd like to have all virtualenvs created from Python distributions installed at the system level (in my case, using the official python.org installers for MacOS).

I've tracked this behaviour to this: https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/blob/master/src/tox/interpreters/unix.py#L14-L15

Is it possible to force the use of base interpreters other than the one tox is running with?
Is this a valid use case for a tox plugin? If so, any hints about how to get started?

Thanks!

labels.description: Issues that have been acknowledged, a solution determined and a PR might likely be accepted.

items.body:
When running tox from within tox in parallel mode, the tox env of the inner tox is changed unlike when running it without parallel mode. This used to work with detox.

## Get the latest tox

```
[totox]$ python3.7 -m venv venv
[totox]$ . venv/bin/activate
(venv) [totox]$ pip install tox
...
Successfully installed filelock-3.0.12 importlib-metadata-0.23 more-itertools-7.2.0 packaging-19.2 pluggy-0.13.0 py-1.8.0 pyparsing-2.4.2 six-1.12.0 toml-0.10.0 tox-3.14.0 virtualenv-16.7.6 zipp-0.6.0
```

## Create an inner project with simple tox.ini

```
(venv) [totox]$ mkdir inner
(venv) [totox]$ cat > inner/tox.ini
[tox]
envlist = py36,py37,py38
skipsdist = True

[testenv]
commands =
    python -c 'import sys; print(sys.version)'

(venv) [totox]$ cd inner
(venv) [inner]$ tox
py36 create: /home/churchyard/tmp/totox/inner/.tox/py36
py36 run-test-pre: PYTHONHASHSEED='3754984691'

____________________________________________________ summary ____________________________________________________
  py36: commands succeeded
  py37: commands succeeded
  py38: commands succeeded
  congratulations :)
(venv) [inner]$ cd ..
```

## See that invoking the inner dir's tox via subprocess works


items.title: installed list is missing system packages like setuptools

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
I guess that the currently code uses the result of `pip freeze` instead of `pip freeze --all` which also includes versions of critical libraries like setuptools.

I ended up creating this bug because I got failures to install dependencies that were caused by differences between these libraries that are hidden by default.

items.title: document portable way to clean folders

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body:
While using tox it is quite common to want to remove some files, directories or even globing before running some commands. This is needed because previous executions may leave leftovers which can affect the final outcome.

Using shell commands like `rm` for `find` is not really cross platform portable, thus I think that tox should document/recommend better ways to perform these.

items.title: passenv: include TERM by default

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body:
I think it would be good to include `TERM` in `passenv` by default, since it gets used with readline(-alike) programs, e.g. pdbpp (via pyrepl), where `setupterm()` then would fail without it being known.

Adding `TERM` to `passenv` explicitly works, but should not really be required, since there is usually no harm being done by passing this through, except for providing information about the used terminal.

doc ref: https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/blame/1883946bd3f233f58928864700eb0e6007332ffd/docs/config.rst#L388-L392
Related issue: https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/issues/250

Affected programs:

- Sphinx, uses no color without a decent TERM

items.title: consider using release-drafter for release notes

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body: I thin that contributions to tox could be make much easier if we start using https://github.com/apps/release-drafter or something similar. I personally started to use it on few packages I maintain and I am really happy as it automatically updates a github draft release note and when you are ready to make a release you already have all the data completed. See https://github.com/pycontribs/selinux/releases

items.title: regression in passing environments via TOXENV

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
Hey devs,

in our project [here](https://github.com/iot-lab/cli-tools) we use tox to unit test, and we experienced a drop in code coverage which went unnoticed, and I finally bisected the problem to b6de3432544c94ee995b0ed3d77b23517d6606c0, first released in version 3.7.0 

The issue is that when passing environments to test (via TOXENV, but the problem might happen when passing the environments to `tox` differently, not sure), then duplicated environments are not run.

Example:

Before, `TOXENV="py27-tests,coverage_upload,py35-tests,coverage_upload" tox` would run two tests, uploading the coverage after each python version

Afterwards, up to the most recent version, the `coverage_upload` env is run only once. I'm not sure where the test environments are dropped or de-duplicated, but it's happening. 

I'll probably rewrite the `tox.ini` so I don't rely on tox running environments twice like that, but I think you should be aware :-)

items.title: Extend default passenv to include SSL proxy vars

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body:
There is a list of 3 environment variables that are also needed for SSL proxies. Tox is currently passing proxy vars but missing to pass the SSL vars and the side effect is clear: called code will choke trying to verify the SSL certificates.

```
CURL_CA_BUNDLE
REQUESTS_CA_BUNDLE
SSL_CERT_FILE
```

I am fully aware that use can manually add them to their tox.ini file but this does not scale well at all when you have hundreds of repositories (like openstack for example).

items.title: Multiple factors aren't respected

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

labels.name: needs:discussion
labels.description: It's not quite clear if and how this should be done

items.body:
This may be a misunderstanding of how `tox` is supposed to work on my end, so apologies if so. Take the following `tox.ini` file:

```ini
[tox]
minversion = 3.1
envlist = py37,functional,pep8
ignore_basepython_conflict = true
skipsdist = true

[testenv]
basepython = python3
whitelist_externals =
  pip
deps =
  requests
commands =
  pip freeze
  python --version

[testenv:functional]
deps =
  {[testenv]deps}
  requests-mock
```

If I run this with `tox -e py37` or `tox -e functional`, things behave as expected. For example:

```shell
$ tox -e functional                                                                                                                                                                                                
functional create: /tmp/tox-test/.tox/functional                                                                                                                                                                   
functional installdeps: requests, requests-mock                                                                                                                                                                    
functional installed: certifi==2019.9.11,chardet==3.0.4,idna==2.8,requests==2.22.0,requests-mock==1.7.0,six==1.12.0,urllib3==1.25.6                                                                                
functional run-test-pre: PYTHONHASHSEED='936107316'                                                                                                                                                                
functional runtests: commands[0] | pip freeze                                                                                                                                                                      
certifi==2019.9.11                                                                                                                                                                                                 
chardet==3.0.4                                                                                                                                                                                                     
idna==2.8                                                                                                                                                                                                          
requests==2.22.0                                                                                                                                                                                                   
requests-mock==1.7.0                                                                                                                                                                                               
six==1.12.0                                                                                                                                                                                                        
urllib3==1.25.6                                                                                                                                                                                                    
functional runtests: commands[1] | python --version                                                                                                                                                                
Python 3.7.4                                                                                                                                                                                                       
_____________________________________________________________________________________________________ summary _____________________________________________________________________________________________________
  functional: commands succeeded                                                                                                                                                                                   
  congratulations :)
```

My understanding of factors suggests that `tox -e functional-py36` should implicitly exist, because `py36` is an auto-generated factor that implies some things (namely, the use of `basepython=python3.6` instead of `python3`). However, this is not the case as seen below. What's worse is that the request isn't even outright rejected - it works, but doesn't do what you'd expect:

```shell
$ tox -e functional-py36
functional-py36 create: /tmp/tox-test/.tox/functional-py36
functional-py36 installdeps: requests
functional-py36 installed: certifi==2019.9.11,chardet==3.0.4,idna==2.8,requests==2.22.0,urllib3==1.25.6
functional-py36 run-test-pre: PYTHONHASHSEED='1866335307'
functional-py36 runtests: commands[0] | pip freeze
certifi==2019.9.11
chardet==3.0.4
idna==2.8
requests==2.22.0
urllib3==1.25.6
functional-py36 runtests: commands[1] | python --version
Python 3.6.9
_____________________________________________________________________________________________________ summary _____________________________________________________________________________________________________
  functional-py36: commands succeeded
  congratulations :)
```

Note that `deps` from `testenv:functional` isn't used. Rather, the value from `testenv` is.

I think that one of the following should happen:

- The environment should use a combination of details from the `functional` testenv and the `py36` testenv. As such, it should install `requests-mock` but use `basepython=python3.6` (preferred!)
- The request should be outright rejected since it's not explicitly listed in `envlist` and isn't one of the auto-generated envs

---

```
$ tox --version
3.5.3 imported from /usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/tox/__init__.py
registered plugins:
    tox-docker-1.4.1 at /home/sfinucan/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/tox_docker.py
```

items.title: setup.cfg parsed differently on Jenkins

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
This bug can be reproduced using this trivial repo: https://github.com/rsokl/tox-bug

### Context
- Using a setup.cfg file instead of tox.ini
- Running tox on Jenkins (i.e. `JENKINS_URL` or `HUDSON_URL` are environment variables are set)

### Problem
The documentation specifies that the setup.cfg file should contain a `[tox:tox]` section. However, on Jenkins, the file is parsed to look for a `[tox]` section instead.

### Example
Consider the simple setup.cfg

```
# contents of setup.cfg
[tox:tox]  # does not work on Jenkins; [tox] does work                          
envlist = py37
toxworkdir = build/tox
```

The `toxworkdir` is set as-expected when tox is run locally (off-Jenkins):
```shell
>>> tox
GLOB sdist-make: /home/rsokl/tox_dummy/setup.py
py37 create: /home/rsokl/tox_dummy/build/tox/py37
```

Running this "on Jenkins", the `[tox:tox]` section is not found and `toxworkdir` fails to get set:
```shell
>>> env JENKINS_URL="" tox
GLOB sdist-make: /home/ry26099/tox_dummy/setup.py
python create: /home/ry26099/tox_dummy/.tox/python
```

Now we can modify the setup.cfg to contain a `[tox]` section, and find inverted behavior
```
# adapted setup.cfg
[tox]  # works on Jenkins; does not work locally                          
envlist = py37
toxworkdir = build/tox
```
Running locally, no tox section is found, which is to be expected since we deviate from the documented `[tox:tox]` form (note that the `toxworkdir` is not set):

```shell
>>> tox
GLOB sdist-make: /home/ry26099/tox_dummy/setup.py
python create: /home/ry26099/tox_dummy/.tox/python
```

But Jenkins does see this tox section (note that the `toxworkdir` *is* properly set):
```shell
>>> env JENKINS_URL="" tox
GLOB sdist-make: /home/ry26099/tox_dummy/setup.py
py37 create: /home/ry26099/tox_dummy/build/tox/py37
```

items.title: tox fails to detect extras installation failure and proceed running tests

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

labels.name: bug:upstream
labels.description: something does not behave as it should, but can't or shouldn't be fixed in tox, but in a dependency

items.body:
In certain conditions `tox 3.14.0` seems to ignore failure to install extras and proceeds running the test commands. Even worse, on subsequent executions it believes that all extras were correctly installed and goes directly to running tests.

This can easily be reproduce on a machine that does not nave python headers (so it cannot compile some reqs).

```
git clone https://github.com/ansible/molecule.git
cd molecule
tox -e py27-ansible27-functional --notest
```
That environment lists most of extras from https://github.com/ansible/molecule/blob/master/setup.cfg#L97-L138 and in my case installing `lxc` extra failed due to being unable to compile lxc-python2. At a result none of the requirements from `test` extras was installed, not even on extra runs.

I tried commenting the custom install_command but the same behavior remained.

tox should never assume that an environment is setup correctly if it failed to install requirements initially. I am not sure how it works internally but this could easily be obtained by using a placeholder that is added only on success execution, so when run again, it will know if it could bypass it or not.

items.title: tox must upgrade Pip in `.tox` env before installing any other dists

labels.name: bug:normal
labels.description: affects many people or has quite an impact

items.body:
I'm hitting the same problem that pytest hit a while back:
https://ci.appveyor.com/project/CherryPy/cheroot/builds/27622282/job/6etbt4hn5hv08x3y#L132

So basically tox does `pip install 'pip >= 9' 'tox-run-command >= 0.4' 'tox >= 3.13.2'` in `.tox` venv but Pip that is invoked is Pip 8.
So this pulls in more-itertools via as a dependency choosing v7.0.0 which is incompatible with Python 2.

I think, it's reasonable to upgrade Pip as a pre-requisite step.

items.title: Prevent environment recreation

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body:
Is there any way to prevent `tox` from re-creating environments if they already exist, no matter what? The `--recreate` option does the opposite: recreate environments no matter what. So, I'd be looking for an explicit `--no-recreate` option (or, change `--recreate` to `--recreate=[auto]/true/false`, although this would deviate from what was discussed in #1372).

I have a couple of use-cases: I have a `tox.ini` for Unix systems and `tox-conda.ini` for Windows which uses `tox-conda`. I'd like to launch a specific tox command e.g. `tox -e linting`  from a script which reuses an existing environment `.tox/py37` that is guaranteed to have been created from a previous tox call, but I don't know whether that previous call was `tox -c tox.ini ...` or `tox -c tox-conda.ini ...`. The problem is that tox will recreate `.tox/py37` if there is any mismatch between the ini files.

Second, for the `tox-conda`-created environments, I was trying to debug some problems with binary incompatibilities of conda packages installed from different channels. To investigate this, I manually ran `conda` commands to un/re-install packages in the `.tox/py37` conda environment. Unfortunately, it seems `tox` or `tox-conda` detects this and recreates the environment, wiping out my changes.

In either case, I just want tox to re-used the existing environment, no questions asked. While I could probably work around the first use case without too much trouble, the second one seems more difficult: I'd like to manually tweak tox environment for debugging and not have to worry whether this might trigger re-creation.

items.title: tox -p without number should enable auto mode

labels.name: feature:new
labels.description: something does not exist yet, but should

items.body:
It would a good improvement in user experience if when adding just `-p`, tox would run in parallel mode, like it does not with `tox -p auto`. This would save 5 keystrokes when calling tox.

I think that `auto` is likely what most people want when they want to run in parallel, so why to ask the to type more for getting it.
